title: AC+DC - Achievements for Global Supply Chains
segmentation: Welcome also from my side to all of you.
Very happy to see this room.
Quite fit and just to add some.
Comment to my person.
So what is my task now?
Just to give you an impression with the merger of Siemens VDO and the former Custom Continental we have now.

A logistics network that consists out of 90 plants worldwide and we have linked to our 90 plus we have 4500 suppliers so I mean that's my used case so to say and I hope we can put a lot of experience and.
And our challenges and their solutions to it to this ACC project.
So you see here the partners.
So this is an integrated project and we have partners all over Europe.
The highlighted ones here in green armor linked to logistic issues.
We have for example here.
Yeah, one remark.
My daughter, you don't find here anymore that is not Fujitsu, so they are.
They got purchased so we have a mixture between companies and also universities and government partners.
So what is the motivation for this project here?
Of course we want to strengthen the European car industry.
Which is, as you know, in the global competition, quite apart for us becausw, you know that all over the world.
The big audience are fighting for the customers and everybody is active everywhere, basically.
So what can you do to stay ahead of the competition?
You have to differentiate and in our case here we of course we have a focus in the project or to also on individuality and not so much the image of the.
The car or the OR the producer, but very much the flexibility.
Um?
And very important in the future, in my opinion, will be to shorten the delivery times.
So you also know that all the big OEM's they have their own project to reduce the delivery time to the end customer and so that is also the motivation.
Because if you are able to serve the customer who wants to buy car in let's say 5 days then you have a competitive advantage becausw.
If if you're just faster then you will hinder the customer to go somewhere else and get the car earlier, so to say.
Yeah, what are new challenges for the automotive supply industry?
Speaking for.
Our selfie for County we are confronted with reduced predictability and that's as well from the supplier side but also from the customer side so.
Development times sort of say from more customer sites at customer site.
They get reduced all the time, so our Phase four launches gets always reduced and we have to be very active and fast to fulfill these short timeframes.
But also on the supplier side we have always events that cannot be predicted.
With the challenge to always be the cost leader and that is major target for County.
Of course we have to deal with suppliers that may not be on the highest level in automotive standards.
And due to that we are always confronted with here and there.
Bad planning or unsufficient preparation of the suppliers for our needs.
Then of course the OEMs demand higher capacity and flexibility.
And also we have to somehow prepare for that and one example could be that as you know we have 90 plus that we also tried to make our network safer by having some some backup plan or vision.
And then of course you have to have the ability to really manage a supply chain.
Like I said, if you have 90 plants and these 90 plants there, not always.
In front of the customer.
But we also have internal relationships.
And.
In the supply chain you also have to manage the suppliers that are most crucial or critical.
For us so again here you see the vision.
Um?
Of course I'm logistics guy.
I'm heading this or have the responsibility for logistics, but of course my biggest wish would be that we also have products that fit to the logistics needs, yeah?
So some of my colleagues say that from a logistics perspective, production is just a disturbance in the supply chain which is.
Cynical, of course, but.
Forward for this project.
We also have to consider that and we need products that really flow smooth to the supply chain and how we want to approach that.
You will see afterwards.
I mean, the less possibility you have for disturbance, the more the smoother the flow will be through the supply chain.
And the better is the chance that you can also deliver your products fast if you don't have too many changes in the whole process.
Disturbances.
So what do we wanna do?
In County mainly of course we want to.
Installer network Dynamic Supply network system.
That means, of course tools, but also processes and for us.
Also training of our people, managing the competency, and through that we have then to be we want to be highly reactive, reliable.
And flexible.
Reliability is that goes without saying with our customers, so we have to be reliable, but the challenge is more suitably flexible and reactive.
And then.
I mean, especially in Europe, the customers they want to have, so to say their own car.
So the OEM's have to build a customized car with a certain color, special seat, special air condition, stuff like that special chassis maybe.
And therefore we have also to make sure that we can manage the varieties that have to be produced in a proper way.
So.
This is a picture that should show that we want to go beyond that.
Maybe well known I recicle approach, so we want to really have a.
Decentralized supply chain planning and execution.
So we want to give everybody in the supply chain the police the possibility to take care on his own by.
Having efficient and efficient planning process that is based on feedback loops, so you need a system that gives the necessary information.
Yeah, volume, also certain events.
Timing to everybody in the supply chain.
And.
Also, we see that we have to give higher responsibility here to the first tier suppliers.
Big cause as OEM's have a lot of 1st year and reduce their amount of work this is maybe natural thing.
And that is that.
Now goes with the reduction of costs.
That would be perfect.
And then the approach should be that we just reduce the complex ability complexity.
And that for sure only goes with our partners.
I mean, there are standards existing, but the further you go down in the supply chain, the more problematic it gets to have still standards and common protocols.
And if we manage to bring these standards?
The most far down to the supply chain.
Then we will be more successful.
We need a close collaboration.
And.
It would be best if we have an optimum and we optimize towards them.
Supply chain optimum and not a local optimum.
Um?

The idea behind you can imagine is that if just one partner is having his own optimum, so he's fully utilized, he has his invest most to the lowest level so that he has sought to say his optimum that maybe not the optimum solution for all the partners around here because they may be facing backlogs and disturbances and inflexibility.
So we are set already, so let's.
Yeah.
Logistic principle or logistic ideal situation?
So if you manage to.
Bring the.
Order or the customer decoupling point, so to say.
Or as it says it said here if we manage to do the customization as late as possible in the supply chain.
And then we have before that point we can run mainly standard projects with little vereins.
And customize very late.
Maybe with easy methods?
Then we are also in the in the position to.
Do you have a shorter delivery time?
Yeah becausw.
Only then the varience explored so to say.
And for that the approach should be that we have before that point modules and.
With the development further development of the car, you know that one more electronics components get into the car.
You also have the chance to create the varience through software.
Yeah, in our factories we have specially in electronics make sure manufacturing have been in many production lines.
We have certain station where you have software flashing for example, and.
You can also that bring to a later point in the supply chain, and this is also should also part of the approach.
Here.
So if you now look at the project structure here.
I will just focus here on the work packages 1000 and 2000.
Of course we have a project governance here that take it takes care of.
Coordination and financial aspects.
With the two main work packages 1000 and 2000, we have a split here between more technical oriented work.
We focus here on.
Advanced mechatronics so this is the combination of mechanic and electronic and also software.
And we have a package that.
Deals with.
Launch software concepts.
And then we have a task that takes care of the validation of the developments in these work packages and that we do here together with Jeff.
And then on the supply on the logistics side.
Here we have what we call dynamic supply network management.
And we have here some sub areas.
So one very important is prediction and planning.
Um?
So let's.
A very challenging issue for tier One or four supplier.
Because the information from the customer is not always the right one and we are sometimes confronted with a challenge too.
Tell the customer that he delivered some wrong figure.
And then we have also to take care of planning consistency.
That means.

I think in in every company you have certainly part several departments who create figures and you have to bring them together like sales scripts, figures, logistic has some information from the plants.
And also finance create some plan that might be something different in that we have here to really find a way to bring these figures together.
Then maybe the most challenging part here is event handling, so this is a lot of people in logistics.
Maybe in every company deal with unforeseen, unpredictable events.
And my impression is that from a development perspective, that area was not under focus that much in the past.
But if you find here a good system to handle these issues, like.
Bankruptcy of suppliers of factory burns down or strikes, or?
I mean, I've if I would tell you the events I had to deal with the last month, we could stay till afternoon.
Yeah, so it's really an issue.
And then we have area where we deal with production and testing.
And.
Be.
Look here after production and technology processes.
Let's mainly to find standards for four factories and management principles.
And.
Also, the modularization of the production.
Also, we take care of.
Distributed development and test.
So just to show the use case here.
So for the mechanical side we have a rear axle and the idea is also here to modular module allies.
The component here and have standard components.
Not so many varients, and then create the varient by just changing software.
So you need of course advanced software development for that and.
Then not by train or having a different variety for the rear axle, change the behavior of the car, but just by changing software idea case.
Enter the use case for the logistics area to see here the logistics supply network for our ESP systems.
That stabilize the car.
If you going to snow and going around the curve so to say and you see here our network for supply of NAFTA, Asia and also European Union.
And of course.
To have a, so to say pilot here to look at the whole networks.
That would be a bit difficult because we of course we have to involve certain people into the project and to make that more easy.
We just focused here on the supply of metal and they do some valve block and.
Los Angeles and Budapest producing the ECU.
And they shipped to Frankfurt.
And here the whole unit gets gets assembled and then shipped to our customer.
And.
Of course, I think we have enough complexity and and partners in the in the whole network to really have a go.
Use case here.
So what are the expected final results?
Of course we want to have a documentation of the implementation of the system we want to implement that then will run the supply chain.
We want to deliver some mythology methodologies.
For supply networks.
The structure should be should follow a toolbox principle.
So that the individual companies can can pick solutions for their individual needs.
Becausw of course other suppliers have different situation, different customers, different suppliers.
Also different products maybe, but we want to make sure that so to say everybody can learn from AC/DC and of course also from County of course.
And you want to also have integrated validation of the system so that we want to really prove for ourselves.

I mean that it's our own need for County and we have we need a system that really works and enables us to to plan better to react better to really colorable, collaborate better with our customers and suppliers and therefore we want to really.
Proof that this dynamic supply loops.
Really work here.
So let's short information on the AC/DC project and questions.
I think we have.
We do that at the end.
If you don't mind.
Thank you very much.
Thank you, mark.
